body: Royal Mail has escaped new price controls after the communications regulator said the universal postal system was working in its current form. Ofcom investigated the company over concerns it no longer had competition in the delivery of letters following the withdrawal of Whistl from the market. Publishing the initial findings of its review, launched last July, the regulator said it would not impose new price caps on the company. “Given the declining letters market, and increased competition in parcels, Ofcom is not proposing to impose new price controls on Royal Mail’s wholesale or retail products.” It added: “The universal postal service is financially sustainable, while current rules and safeguards for people and businesses who use post are generally working well.” Shares in Royal Mail rose 1.8% to 530p after Ofcom delivered the findings, making it one of the FTSE 100’s biggest risers on Wednesday morning. Ofcom said that, as the postal regulator, it had a duty to secure the universal postal service, which requires Royal Mail to deliver to every address in the UK, six days a week, at a uniform price. Royal Mail could do more to improve efficiency to benefit customers, Ofcom said, because there was too much variation in performance at different delivery depots. The regulator added that it intended to introduce new rules to ensure the safe arrival of letters. Postal operators which failed to follow these rules would be fined. Jonathan Oxley, competition director at Ofcom, said: “Consumers should have utmost confidence in using postal services. We want to ensure that letters which haven’t been tracked, but may still contain important contents, arrive safely.” The regulator said it was concerned Royal Mail had the potential to subsidise its parcels business through its letters business – where it has a much larger market share and established delivery network - in a way that might disadvantage other parcel delivery companies. “Ofcom will closely monitor whether Royal Mail is appropriately allocating its costs between parcels and letters,” it said. The regulator said it would publish a final report later in the year, following a further consultation period that will close on 3 August. Royal Mail said in response to Ofcom’s initial findings: “Royal Mail notes that Ofcom has today published its consultation document containing proposals in relation to the regulatory framework for Royal Mail.  “The company is reviewing the proposals and will issue a further announcement in due course.”
webTitle: Royal Mail escapes price caps after Ofcom says service working well
